etymology.description: 不 + 客气 = not be (overly) polite/formal.
etymology.interpretation: Literally ‘don’t be polite,’ it downplays thanks as “you’re welcome.” In broader use it tells someone not to stand on ceremony and to speak or act freely.
etymology.simplification: 氣 → 气 under character simplification to reduce strokes; 客氣 → 客气, 不 unchanged.

parts.english: polite; courteous; to stand on ceremony; formal

examples.chinese: 谢谢你(謝謝你)，不客气(不客氣)。
我们都是朋友(我們都是朋友)，有什么需要就说(有什麼需要就說)，不客气一点(不客氣一點)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen dōu shì péngyou, yǒu shénme xūyào jiù shuō, bú kèqi yìdiǎn.
examples.english: We’re all friends—say what you need and don’t be too polite.

examples.chinese: 他帮了我一个小忙(他幫了我一個小忙)，我道谢后他说不客气(我道謝後他說不客氣)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bāng le wǒ yí ge xiǎo máng, wǒ dàoxiè hòu tā shuō bú kèqi.
examples.english: He did me a small favor; after I thanked him, he said “you’re welcome.”
